simplified: Dreams can show us things we didn't know we were thinking about. People usually have dreams like flying or falling, their teeth falling out or being naked in public. But to understand what they mean to you, you need to connect them to your daily life.
In Moscow, there are approximately 35,000 wild dogs living on the streets. They have learned that it is safer to cross the street with people and some dogs appear to understand traffic lights.

New York, New York is a city in the United States. On the street, people are very different. A girl with a facial deformity was seen. Many schools talk about bullying and friendship. A film is being made, and people are waiting to see what happens next.

Chloe has two pet rats, Zena and Roxy. Chloe knows they're not typical pets and she has lost count of the times she's patiently tried to explain to people that rats aren't dirty and they make fantastic pets if you look after them correctly. But she understands why people react badly. She didn't like rats either until her friend Martin showed her his pet rats and she saw how affectionate and intelligent they were. Last year, when one of Martin's rats had babies, Chloe decided she'd like to have two of them.

Cape Town can be a dangerous place for baboons. Baboons are an endangered species. To save them and minimize conflicts between humans and baboons, the city council has a team of Baboon Monitors. The monitors chase baboons out of urban areas or catch them and release them in the countryside. The policy has had some success, but it's hard to stop baboons from coming back to the city once they see it as a source of easy food.

I work from home because our company is in the United States. I don't have to go to the office and I can make my own schedule. I can work on a project basis, which is good for me because I can take time off to go to my kids' school plays or to the dentist. However, I sometimes work late into the evening because I don't have a fixed schedule.

In the 90s, graffiti continued but there was an explosion of street art all over the world. Some people wanted to make a message and produced art that tried to make you think about war, inequality and discrimination. Other people were only concerned with producing beautiful work. In South America, street artists went to work in poor areas and added colour, life and beauty to grey city walls.

Social media, magazines, and shop windows bombard people daily with things to buy, and British people are buying more clothes and shoes than ever before. Online shopping means it is easy for customers to buy without thinking, while big brands offer cheap clothes that can be used a few times and then thrown away.

Sam squinted against the sun. The horses kicked their tails at flies. Sam waited. Mr Carter didn't come out unless he had to. Sam kept out of his boss's way. The boss wiped sweat from his neck. The damp patches on his shirt drew together. His skin was already ruddy. Otherwise, he had the indoor tan of a man who made money while others did the work.

Many people in Berlin, Germany complained that shooting pigs was unnecessarily cruel and there were heated arguments between hunters and animal lovers. In response to protests, the city council decided to take more peaceful action against pigs. Instead of shooting them, they have put up fences and made it illegal to feed the pigs. Time will tell if this strategy works, though it may be a losing battle as warmer winters mean that pig numbers are greater than in the past.

Suzanne's love of classical Greek mythology is one of the most important inspirations for the Hunger Games book. When she was a child, one of her favourite stories was Theseus and the Minotaur. In this story the city of Athens was ruled by Crete, but the Athenians rebelled. As a punishment, Minos the king of Crete forces the Athenians to send seven boys and seven girls to Crete every year. The youths were thrown into the labyrinth and eaten by a monster that lives there called the Minotaur. But one of the youths, named Theseus, fought the Minotaur and killed it. Suzanne sees Katniss Everdeen as a futuristic Theseus.

By bringing people together, zoos can educate the public about conservation and inspire people to protect animals and their habitats. Some zoos provide a safe environment for animals that have been mistreated in circuses or pets that have been abandoned. Zoos also do important research into animal behaviour and how to treat illnesses.

The 'buy nothing' trend is a different way of life. It originated in Canada in the 90s and moved to the US. People organise protests and cut up their credit cards. Throughout the year, people exchange and repair items they already own.

Is graffiti art or vandalism? This depends on your point of view, but in many countries, writing or painting on public or private property is considered vandalism. Many street artists have been stopped by the police and some have had to pay fines. Many city councils complain about the high cost of cleaning graffiti off buildings, buses, and trains.

The art world is recognizing the value of graffiti and street art. Recently, there have been exhibitions in Paris, London, and Los Angeles. The American artist Elura Emerald organized a street art exhibition in New York in 2008. She said that street artists should be appreciated and celebrated because they're just expressing themselves, not hurting anyone.

If most people have four to six dreams every night after the age of ten, that's as many as 2,000 dreams per year. So, by the time they reach 80 years old, the average person might have had 140,000 dreams. Even if we forget 95–99 percent of our dreams, that's still a few thousand remembered dreams across a lifetime. It's not too difficult to believe that, by coincidence, a dream event is followed by a real-life event that's similar to it, especially if the subject of the dream is something that happens often in everyday life.

The Hunger Games takes place in a country called Panem, which is made up of twelve districts. The Capitol is very powerful. Each district provides different things for the Capitol. District 12 gives coal. There was a 13th district, but they rebelled and were destroyed.

Wild animals come into cities to look for food. In Cape Town, South Africa, baboons have started coming into residential areas on the edge of the city to feed. They open rubbish bins and eat fruit from gardens and orchards. Some brave baboons have even come into people's houses and taken food from kitchen cupboards and fridges! Baboons can be aggressive and have attacked a lot of pet animals, so understandably, many city residents don't welcome their presence.

A lot of bridge accidents happen when the bridge is being built. These accidents are often because of a mistake made by the engineers, like a calculation. The bridge falls down and this can be bad for the people working on it.

George Lucas was one of the first film directors to use a story. He tells a story about a man who has an ordinary life, but something happens that calls him to an adventure. When Luke starts the story, he lives with his aunt and uncle, fixing robots. When he finds a message, it is the call to adventure that starts the hero on his journey.
The astronauts will use a weapon to destroy the asteroid in case it gets too close to Earth.

The hero at first refuses the call to adventure, but a mentor appears who helps them and they decide to cross the threshold and travel into the special world where the adventure happens. The next stage consists of passing tests, fighting enemies and meeting friends as the hero prepares to face their biggest challenge. For Luke the mentor is, of course, Obi-Wan, the friends are Han Solo and the robots R2D2 and C3PO and the enemy is Darth Vader inside the special world of the Death Star.

Underutilised items can be useful to some people. They can make money from sharing them. With the internet, people can sell things they don't need on websites and social media groups. This is called the sharing economy.
Freud believed that if we understand what dreams are telling us, we can understand our hidden feelings and the problems they cause.

I'm a freelancer and work for myself. This is great because I am in control of what I do and how I spend my time. At first, I was working from home, but I found it really hard to concentrate. There were just too many distractions around: housework that needed doing, another cup of tea, my family members wanting my attention for various things. So I started to go to a nearby café to work, but the Wi-Fi connection wasn't ideal and I found myself drinking too much coffee. In the end, I decided to rent a desk in a co-working space with five other freelancers like myself. I liked getting dressed to go to work in the morning and being able to focus in an office environment.

Whether NASA can find the remaining middle-sized NEOs depends on getting the money to build NEOCam, a space telescope which would use infrared light to locate asteroids. If it does get the money, it could probably achieve its goal in ten years. Once logged, the planetary defence team would still need to work out how to defend the planet against being hit by the truly worrying asteroids – the PHAs.

The 'buy nothing' trend has now reached influencers on social media who usually share posts of clothing and make-up that they recommend for people to buy. Some YouTube stars now encourage their viewers not to buy anything at all for periods as long as a year. Two friends in Canada spent a year working towards buying only food. For the first three months they learned how to live without buying electrical goods, clothes or things for the house. For the next stage, they gave up services, for example haircuts, eating out at restaurants or buying petrol for their cars. In one year, they'd saved $55,000.
Pi doesn't want to choose one religion. He just wants to love God. His family and teachers are surprised. They let him decide.

Lucid dreams are dreams where you're not only aware you're dreaming but you can make decisions to affect the events of your dreams. So, maybe you can turn a nightmare into a safe-feeling dream, or you can direct the plot of your dream like a film director. Then, instead of just working out the meaning of your dreams, you'll be creating them. You might want to continue having some dreams that allow your subconscious to tell you what's on your mind.
Huge quantities of clothes are thrown away, and a lot of clothes that charities can't sell are sent abroad.

Not content with one amazing trip, some adventurers go from challenge to challenge. Meagan McGrath from Canada climbed the highest mountain on each continent, rode a bike across Canada, and ran a long-distance race in the Sahara Desert in 45ºC heat. But perhaps her most remarkable journey was a skiing trip to the South Pole. On the first day, she fell into a glacier and had to be rescued. Many of us would have given up at that point, but Meagan decided to carry on. She reached the South Pole forty days later, having pulled a sledge with a tent and all her food behind her through freezing conditions and ice storms.
Blek le Rat started painting rats on the walls of his home city, Paris. Nowadays, he paints pictures of homeless people to make people think about the problem of homelessness.

In some areas, councils have tried to encourage artists not to paint graffiti randomly on walls by allowing them to work in designated areas. Taiwan is one such place and there are 'graffiti zones' where artists are free to paint and write on walls. In São Paulo in Brazil, the city council has even allowed some graffiti artists to paint on the subway trains.

Faith47 is from Cape Town in South Africa. She paints big colourful pictures of people and animals and likes to explore different locations. Her work is found on pavements, in empty factories and on abandoned cars. She likes the fact that most street art is temporary and will soon be removed by weather or cleaners from the city council. For her, this reflects how life is full of change with its cycle of endings and new beginnings.

In Gabriela's previous work place, she was used to a high power distance culture where power and authority are respected and everyone has their rightful place. In such a culture, leaders make the big decisions and are not often challenged. Her Swedish team, however, were used to working in a low power distance culture where subordinates often work together with their bosses to find solutions and make decisions. Here, leaders act as coaches or mentors who encourage independent thought and expect to be challenged.

Gabriela's team members weren't happy with her leadership. They didn't like being told what to do. They enjoyed having more freedom. When she told them what she wanted, they felt she didn't trust them. They realised she was taking it personally when they tried to change her decisions. They explained they'd always worked that way.

Os Gêmeos are twin brothers from São Paulo. They paint everything from tags to huge pictures on the sides of buildings. They need big cranes to help them work. In 2007, they covered the whole castle with paint.

In prehistoric times, people painted pictures of animals and people in caves. Graffiti has been found on buildings at ancient sites in Greece, Italy, Syria and Iraq. In the Roman town of Pompeii, archaeologists have found numerous examples of graffiti written in Latin. These include religious, political and romantic messages, and even some magic spells!

Have you ever dreamt of climbing Mount Everest or walking to the South Pole? No, nobody else has done that. Lots of people try to climb the world's highest mountains or walk across continents. They use modern technology like GPS and satellite phones. Some people love nature and help raise awareness about the environment. Others want to help people in need and raise money for charities.

The first is DART – the Double Asteroid Redirection Test. Plans are to test DART on the moon of an asteroid called Didymos. 'Didymoon' is 150 metres wide, and hopefully the impact of DART will knock it out of its orbit enough for Earth-based telescopes to pick up.

Katniss Everdeen, a sixteen year old girl, has lost her father in a mining accident. She hunts in the woods with her friend Gale and becomes very good with a bow and arrow. When her sister, Prim, is chosen as one of the tributes, Katniss volunteers to go instead. The other tribute from District 12 is a boy named Peeta. Katniss soon finds herself in a complicated relationship with Peeta.

Writing about your dreams can help you remember more details about them. If you think about the people and place where the dream happened, it might add to the meaning. After a week, you'll be surprised at how much you've written. Now you can start connecting your dreams to your daily life.

Historically, most bridges were made of wood and were very easy to catch on fire. This was especially true of old-fashioned train bridges, where the spark from the steel wheels and tracks could sometimes cause a bridge to catch fire and burn to the ground.

Street art is becoming more popular, and street artists are getting more recognition. While street artists are mostly young people, more and more street artists are traveling around the world. They are using the internet to communicate and share photos of their work. As a result, the art world is recognizing street art as a legitimate art form. Even if we don't know what the future holds, we can be sure that street art will continue to exist.

Suzanne Collines was upset by news programmes about wars. When she was a child, her dad was a pilot in the US Air Force and he fought in Vietnam. Her mom protected her by not telling her what was happening in the war, but she still watched news programmes and knew that her dad was there. It was scary for her.
In a survey of 40,000 millennials, they answered questions about their work and life.

Erik Weihenmayer is a multi-adventurer. He is blind. He has been blind since he was 13. Erik rides a bike through the deserts of Morocco. Erik kayaks through the Grand Canyon. Erik climbed Everest. Erik encourages people with disabilities. Erik takes groups of young blind people on climbing trips.

Democratised marketplaces are giving people a chance to make some money. To give an example, parents can sell their children's old things, like clothes and equipment, to earn some cash back into their pockets.

Pi and Richard Parker spend 227 days in the lifeboat. They live through hunger, illness and exhaustion. They endure violent storms and the burning heat of the Pacific sun, but somehow they survive. At times, Pi finds comfort in his three religions, but at other times he is overcome with loneliness and despair. Finally, the Mexican coast appears on the horizon and everything changes. It would be a shame to give away the ending, so you will have to read the book yourself to find out what happens to Pi and Richard Parker once land is in sight.
Chloe went home from school and had a cup of coffee. She was quiet for an hour before her parents came home. She liked playing with her pet rats.

In 2010, NASA had found 90% of the big rocks near Earth. These rocks are as big as mountains and are near the Earth's path. There are 50 left to find. NASA says none of the rocks are a big danger to the Earth.

Having decided to go to school, Auggie then has to face his first day. Like every child starting at a new school, he is really anxious. But because of the way he looks, it's an agonising experience. Nobody wants to sit next to him and he notices other kids staring at him or talking about him behind their hands. Fortunately, he makes friends with Jack, a boy in his class, and Summer, a girl he chats with at lunch. But it's not just the first day that's hard. Auggie soon learns that his classmates don't want to touch him for fear of catching 'the plague'. As he goes through the school year, Auggie goes through many intense ups and downs till finally an unexpected and traumatic event at a school camp changes things completely.

The two men looked at the northern end of the property. It stretched as far as the eye could see. Even if a boy got bored, he couldn't escape on foot. Sam looked at the biggest horse, kicking at the ground with its heavy hooves. Could the boy ride? he wondered. There was trouble for a good rider, but maybe more trouble for someone who knew nothing about horses and wanted to get away from his father.

Over 4,000 people, from 13 to 80 years old, have climbed Everest. Though climbing in the mountains is still dangerous, the best climbers now look for new challenges. Gerlinde Kaltenbrunner from Austria fell in love with mountain climbing when she was a teenager. When she left school, she worked as a nurse, but she kept climbing in her free time.

Gerlinde climbed the 8,000 meter peaks without oxygen tanks. This is risky because low oxygen levels can affect brain and body functioning. Gerlinde uses her fame to support a charity for poor children in Nepal.

I have a thick coat that I bought last year. I thought it was a good idea to buy it at the time, but now it just looks like a thing I own. It's not being used much, and I even think about turning it into a storeroom for some of my old things.

Throughout history and across cultures, people have believed that dreams are messages from gods sent to give us knowledge or insight. Many people can recall a time they dreamed about an event, place or person, and then, later, the dream came true in real life.

Some of the biggest and most expensive transportation projects in the world have been building bridges. Bridges are very important links that carry cars, trucks and trains across bodies of water, mountain gorges or other roads. As a result, they are one of the most important aspects of civil engineering and are subject to intense scrutiny, especially when they collapse.

After weeks of frustration, Gabriela emailed her manager about the problems she was facing with her team. Her manager simply asked her if she felt her team was still working, and what she thought would help her work better with her team members. Gabriela found her manager vague and didn't feel as if he was managing the situation satisfactorily.

The dogs have learnt to use the metro to get from one part of their territory to another. They use their sense of smell to get off the train. They have also learnt to recognize the names of stations they hear in announcements. People have grown used to seeing dogs on the trains, and now they travel largely unnoticed.

Ed Stafford from the UK is the first person to walk the length of the Amazon River. He started by a small stream in the Andes mountains of Peru and arrived at the river's mouth in Brazil two years and four months later, having walked 6,000 kilometres. The Amazon rainforest is full of snakes, crocodiles and jaguars. Ed was in constant danger. Luckily, he survived with only a few mosquito and ant bites.

In Britain, the average person spends more than £1,000 on clothes a year, which is around four per cent of their income. That might not sound like much, but that figure hides two far more worrying trends for society and for the environment. First, a lot of that spending is via credit cards. British people currently owe approximately £670 per adult to credit card companies. That's 66 per cent of the average wardrobe budget. Also, not only are people spending money they don't have, they're using it to buy things they don't need. Britain throws away 300,000 tons of clothes a year, most of which goes into landfill sites.

Ed used a radio to ask people for food and permission to cross the land. He walked through difficult terrain with the help of many people. He wrote a blog to share his experiences and raise money for charities. He used the media to protest about the destruction of the rainforest.

Companies like Airbnb act as a middleman for people to cash in on their unused rooms and houses and let them out as lucrative accommodation. Companies like Uber encourage people to use their own personal cars as taxis to make some extra cash in their free time.

The zoo will provide a safe environment for the animals, which is very important for their survival. The animals are endangered, and they need a safe place to live and breed. The zoo will help increase the diversity of the animals by releasing zoo-bred animals into the wild. This will help the animals to live and breed in a secure environment, which is very important for their survival. The zoo will provide a safe environment for the animals, which is very important for their survival. The animals are endangered, and they need a safe place to live and breed. The zoo will help increase the diversity of the animals by releasing zoo-bred animals into the wild. This will help the animals to live and breed in a secure environment, which is very important for their survival. Boats and trains can cause bridges to collapse. Trains bring down bridges because they have a lot of speed. Boats bring down bridges because they are very heavy. The best way to avoid bridge failures is to plan for them. Modern technologies and safer working environments can help reduce accidents.

Pi is scared of the animals and jumps into the ocean. Then he remembers that there are sharks in the water and realises that he must climb back into the lifeboat. One by one, the animals in the lifeboat kill and eat each other, till only Pi and a tiger are left. Fortunately for Pi, the tiger is seasick and has no interest in eating him.
Pi's family and the ship's sailors all drowned, but Pi found himself in a lifeboat with a hyena, zebra, orang-utan, and an enormous tiger.

The Hunger Games is a huge book for young people written by Suzanne Collins. Since it was published in 2008 it has been translated into 26 languages and has sold millions of copies. It is now a successful film. It made a lot of money in its first weekend.

Maybe our mind is working on our dreams when we're asleep. But when we're awake, our thoughts mostly appear in our minds as words, like conversations we have with ourselves. But when we're asleep, the part of our brain that controls language becomes less active while the part that controls emotions becomes more active.

Having good relationships is a big part of being happy. Most happy people have friends and family who they spend time with. You also need someone you can talk to about your feelings. Just one person is enough. Having lots of friends is not enough. You need a deeper connection with someone. Some people need to learn how to listen to others to have stronger relationships.

Psychologist and 'growth mindset' proponent Carol Dweck talked about the plasticity of the brain and how people can develop new skills. Many people focus on the end result and the talents they have, but by praising effort and trying different things, we can help people develop new skills and talents.

The rover analyses the air around it periodically, and in 2014 it found the air contained another of the most basic organic molecules and a key ingredient of natural gas: methane. One of the characteristics of methane is that it only survives a few hundred years. This means that something, somewhere on Mars, is replenishing the supply. According to NASA, Mars emits thousands of tons of methane at a time. The level of methane rises and falls at seasonal intervals in the year, almost as if the planet is breathing it.

Carol Dweck, a psychologist, gave a group of ten-year-olds some problems. One group was happy and said they liked challenges. She said they had a 'growth mindset'. But another group felt sad and thought their intelligence was being judged. They had a 'fixed mindset' and couldn't imagine improving. Some kids said they might cheat in the future. Others looked for someone who had done worse than them to boost their self-esteem.

Horror movies love being in uninhabited places. These can be an empty house, a ghost town, or an abandoned hospital. Being alone can be very scary. What was life like for people who lived there? Why did they leave? Maybe it's that it's so quiet, which can be very scary too. These places are also useful for horror film directors because they can make it seem like there is no phone signal.

No matter what kind of house it is, the basement is a scary place in horror films. That's usually where something is hiding or where the bad guy has hidden his tools. Basements are always dark and often damp. You can only reach them by a narrow staircase. And basements are always scary, even when there isn't anything down there.

Gary Collins, an off-duty cop, was watching the London riots on TV. He immediately recognised several people and cut his holiday short to help with identification. He ended up spending six months going through the CCTV film and managed to identify 190 people, many from their eyes alone. His help was of decisive importance in the investigation. Even with 200,000 hours of footage, facial recognition software managed to identify just one person.

To consider something is to think about it. We are going to speed up our evolution by giving our bodies more power. We will be able to do things better, remember more, and hear more clearly. This idea is becoming more popular. We will soon be able to do all these things with computers inside our heads. This idea will become more and more popular.
You see it all the time with your daughter and her friends. They arrange to meet and then sit together in silence while each one engages in a different conversation online.
Between the end of World War II and 1990, there were 30 wars that killed more than 100,000 people.

Wasfia is a very dedicated person who has seen many projects to help women and girls in her homeland, but they often have nothing when the projects stop. Wasfia decided to combine mountaineering and human rights to try to change the attitudes towards women in her country. She originally started climbing while working on humanitarian projects in Tibet and Nepal, because most people in her flat country have never seen a mountain. Her campaign seems to be working, and many people are starting to take notice, including the rest of the world.

The reality is that a great transformation is occurring, as over the past 20 years, more than 700 million people have increased their income and come out of poverty, and six million fewer children die every year from disease, millions more girls are in school, and millions of people have access to clean water.

In an attempt to make things better, many managers use positive comments to soften the negative feedback they give their employees. However, if feedback becomes a regular thing, employees may start to think positive feedback is just a way to cover up the bad stuff, which makes it less useful. Instead, managers should give positive feedback so that it helps employees do better and be more confident.

I'm a member of a campaign to stop machines that can kill with very little human input. Forget the movie image of machines like drones and gun turrets that are already used to kill people. Think of what's happening right now: these machines are being used to kill with very little human input. The next step will be machines that can decide who to kill on their own. It seems clear that this would be very bad for humanity. We need to be very careful about what we ask machines to do.

Overall, more people speak English than any other language. However, Chinese has the most native speakers. There seems to be no big connection between the number of native speakers and the number of people who learn the language. But there is a stronger link between the number of people who learn the language and the number of countries that speak it.

Your manager stops you and says she needs to have a word about your performance in the recent project. You worry about it all weekend, wondering what you might have done wrong. When you step into her office on Monday morning she begins by praising you for the good work you've done on the project, and you wonder if this is the obligatory praise that starts off the typical 'feedback sandwich'. You know how the feedback sandwich goes: say something nice, say what you really want to say, say something nice again. You'll be there until the trial. This is where the fun begins. It's not good for business.

A fast-paced, foot-tapping rock album, Born in the USA's lyrics carry emotional weight. Behind the catchy rock melodies that drive these powerful songs are stories of the dark side of the American dream. Many tracks deal with the struggles of ordinary people and the bitterness they feel as life doesn't bring them riches or glory. The song Glory Days tells the story of people in a small town looking back at when they were young and had the world at their feet. The album will leave you no doubt about the unique talent of the artist.

Lewis wants to see more marine areas in the world. He has seen the damage caused by humans. He swam over coral reefs and saw plastic in the Red Sea.  He thinks nature can recover if we leave it alone. But if we don't take care of the seas, we will have a big problem.

Terrie Sharp is a popular author. She was born in a housing estate in Glasgow. She learned to keep quiet and stay out of trouble. She has won the Olive Crime Writer Award twice. She now appears on daytime shows and writes books.

Are things getting worse every day? Is progress an impossible goal? In Enlightenment Now, Steven Pinker looks at the big picture of human progress and finds good news. We are living longer, healthier, freer and happier lives. The real problem, Pinker argues, is that the Enlightenment values of reason and science are under attack. When commentators and demagogues appeal to people's tribalism, fatalism and distrust, then we are in danger of causing irreparable damage to important institutions like democracy and world co-operation.

In older horror films, when protagonists were in desperation, it was difficult or impossible for them to call for help or call the police. Mobile phones have made that situation a bit less believable now. What's the solution to maintain suspense? No phone coverage! If you're a hero in a horror film, it's almost certain that at a key moment, just when you absolutely need to call for help, you will not have any coverage at all. Or your phone battery will die just as you are making the call. Or both.

In the 50s, Central American banana growers were facing the death of their most lucrative product, the Gros Michel banana. And now it's happening again to Big Mike's successor – the Cavendish. With its easily transported, thick-skinned fruit, the Gros Michel banana plant dominated the plantations of Central America. United Fruit, the main grower, mass-produced its bananas in the most efficient way possible: it cloned shoots from the stems of plants instead of growing plants from seeds, and cultivated them in densely packed fields.

Australia's most venomous spider, the Sydney funnel-web spider, has not killed anyone since anti-venom was developed in 1981. You should be careful around hairy spiders like tarantulas, which will defend themselves by ejecting urticating hairs if they feel threatened. Don't rub them the wrong way. They will defend themselves by sending a cloud of irritating hairs to your skin or eyes.
The last girl usually wins in the end. She starts off as innocent, shy and weak. By the end, she is the toughest and most resourceful person in the world.

If we want to know where our ability to speak came from, we need to look at how our brains are different from other animals. This relates to more than just brain size; it is important what other things our brains can do and when and why they evolved that way. And for this there are very few physical clues; artefacts left by our ancestors don't tell us what speech they were capable of making. One thing we can see in the remains of early humans, however, is the development of the mouth, throat and tongue. By about 100,000 years ago, humans had evolved the ability to create complex sounds. Before that, evolutionary biologists can only guess whether or not early humans communicated using more basic sounds.

Girls should favour arts and humanities, not maths and physics. Girls don't see many positive female role models doing science-related jobs. Cartoons often show crazy scientists, genius inventors, or adventurous astronauts as men. There is a perception that scientists are geeky, have poor social skills, or that their work is lonely and detached from the rest of the world. This perception may mean that girls don't identify with scientists and see science as an unappealing career path. If girls saw more positive female role models in science, it would give them more confidence and a greater sense of belonging in those subjects.

The Scallion is printed weekly and distributed free in faculty buildings, with a readership of approximately 10,000 students. It is written and produced entirely by students. The survey shows that the newspaper is highly valued by university students and staff for entertainment, cultural enrichment and work experience. The cost of printing newspapers is significant. Furthermore, some students do not have easy access to the paper, since the only way to obtain a copy is to physically go to university. An additional environmental issue is that a large number of copies end up as litter on campus.

At Girox Foods, we are on 12 people leaving the company. Although this might not seem high at first, the firm standard is 7 people leaving. The main goal of this report is to find the reasons why the employees are unhappy and, based on those, give some tips to make them happy and keep them in the company.

So much of what the speaker said rang true. I honestly believe there's a danger that the more connected we are, the more isolated we feel. I don't think this is such an issue for my generation who've lived without technology for so long. We know how to be alone and, more importantly, we know that it's OK to be alone. But the under 20s are another kettle of fish. They're so busy communicating that they never experience the feeling of solitude and run the risk of not learning how to enjoy their own company. In addition, they're learning conversation through messages that can be edited and changed at the expense of learning the art of real conversation in real time with the person in front of you.
Don't ignore good feedback just because of bad feedback.

Your dreams might show you all kinds of things that you didn't realise you were thinking about. Common dreams like flying or falling probably mean something similar in most people. But the key to understanding exactly what they mean to you is to connect them to the events and feelings in your daily life.

In Moscow, there are about 35,000 wild dogs living on the streets. Some dogs were born in the wild, while others are pets that have been abandoned by their owners. They live alone or in packs. In 2010, scientists studied the dogs and found that they have adapted remarkably well to urban life. They have learned that it is safer to cross the street with people and some dogs appear to understand traffic lights.

Wonder is New Yorker RJ Palacio's first novel. She explains that the idea for the book came to her after seeing a girl with facial deformities on the street one day. Wonder has been a bestseller in the US and has already won several awards. Many schools are using it as a starting point for discussions about bullying, friendship and what it's like to be different. A film version is being made and many people are waiting eagerly to see what RJ Palacio writes next.

Chloe has two pet rats, Zena and Roxy. Chloe knows they're not typical pets and she has lost count of the times she's patiently tried to explain to people that rats aren't dirty and they make fantastic pets if you look after them correctly. But she understands why people react badly. She didn't like rats either until her friend Martin showed her his pet rats and she saw how affectionate and intelligent they were. Last year, when one of Martin's rats had babies, Chloe decided she'd like to have two of them. (B1)

Cape Town can be a difficult place for baboons. Some have been injured or killed in car accidents and others have been electrocuted as they played with electric cables. Baboons are an endangered species and to save them and minimise conflicts between humans and baboons, the city council has employed a team of Baboon Monitors. The monitors' job is to chase baboons out of urban areas or catch them and release them in the countryside. This policy has had some success, though it is proving hard to stop baboons from coming back to the city once they see it as a source of easy food.

I work for a company based in the US, but because their headquarters is in the States, I do all my work online from my home. This flexibility is very valuable to me because it means I can easily take time off when my children need me to go to their school performances or if I need to schedule an appointment with the dentist. The downside is that without clear office hours, I tend to work well into the evening, sometimes skipping dinner to finish a task.

In the 1990s, graffiti continued but there was also an explosion in street art around the world. Some artists wanted to make political points and produced art that tried to make people think about war, inequality and discrimination. Other street artists were more concerned with producing beautiful, attractive work. In South America, many street artists went to work in poor areas adding colour, life and beauty to grey, city walls.
Social media, magazines and shop windows bombard people daily with things to buy, and British consumers are buying more clothes and shoes than ever before.

Sam waited. Mr Carter didn't come out here unless he had to, which was just fine by Sam. The more he kept out of his boss's way, the longer he'd have a job. Mr Carter wiped the sweat from the back of his neck. The damp patches on his shirt drew together like shapes in an atlas. His skin was already turning ruddy in the June sun. Otherwise he had the indoor tan of a man that made money while other people did the work.

Many city people in Berlin, Germany were unhappy with shooting pigs and there were arguments between hunters and animal lovers. The city council decided to take a peaceful approach against pigs. Instead of shooting them, they put up fences and made it illegal to feed the pigs. The future will tell if this is a good strategy, but it may be a losing battle because warmer winters mean that pig numbers are greater than in the past.
Suzanne sees Katniss Everdeen as a futuristic Theseus.

By bringing together people and animals, zoos can educate the public about conservation issues and inspire people to protect animals and their habitats. Some zoos provide a safe environment for animals that have been mistreated in circuses, or pets that have been abandoned. Zoos also conduct important research into animal behaviour and how to treat illnesses.

A different trend is springing up in opposition to consumerism – the 'buy nothing' trend. This movement originated in Canada in the early 1990s and has spread to the US, where it's a reaction against Black Friday and Cyber Monday during Thanksgiving weekend. On Buy Nothing Day, people protest and cut up their credit cards. Throughout the year, Buy Nothing groups arrange the exchange and repair of items they already own.

Is graffiti art or vandalism? This depends on your point of view, but in many countries, writing or painting on public buildings is considered vandalism. Many street artists have been stopped by the police and some have had to pay fines. Many city councils complain about the high cost of cleaning graffiti off buildings, buses and trains.

The art world has started to value street art. Recently, exhibitions of street art have been held in galleries in Paris, London and Los Angeles. The American artist Elura Emerald organised a street art exhibition at a New York gallery in 2008. She defended street artists, saying 'They should be appreciated and celebrated'.

If most people have four to six dreams every night after the age of ten, that's as many as 2,000 dreams per year. So, by the time they reach 80 years old, the average person might have had 140,000 dreams. Even if we forget 95–99 per cent of our dreams, that's still a few thousand remembered dreams across a lifetime. It's not too difficult to believe that, by coincidence, a dream event is followed by a real-life event that's similar to it, especially if the subject of the dream is something that happens often in everyday life.

The Hunger Games takes place in the future, after the destruction of North America. The country is called Panem and is made up of twelve poor districts governed by the wealthy Capitol. The Capitol holds absolute power over the nation. Each district is responsible for producing different things for the Capitol. District 12, where the story begins, provides all the coal for the country. There used to be a thirteenth district but they rebelled against the Capitol in the past and were destroyed.

In Cape Town, South Africa, baboons have started coming into residential areas to feed. They open bins and eat fruit from gardens and orchards. Some brave baboons even enter people's houses and take food from kitchen cupboards and fridges. Baboons can be aggressive, so city residents don't welcome their presence.

A large number of bridge accidents happen during the construction of a bridge. These accidents often happen because of a mistake made by the engineers. The bridge collapses under its own weight, and this can be very dangerous for the people working on it at the time.

George Lucas was one of the first film directors to directly base his story on the 17 stages of the hero's journey. Typically, the hero starts his story living an ordinary life, but something happens that calls him to an adventure that changes everything. At the beginning of Star Wars, Luke lives an ordinary life with his aunt and uncle, repairing robots. When he finds Princess Leia's message to Obi-Wan Kenobi inside the robot R2D2, it is 'the call to adventure' that starts the hero on his journey.

A suggested defence against a PHA on course to hit Earth is to blow it up using a nuclear weapon. The Hypervelocity Asteroid Mitigation Mission for Emergency Response (HAMMER) is a genuine NASA proposal. The eight-ton rockets would be fired at an approaching asteroid with the hope of bumping it off course. If the asteroid was too close to Earth, the rockets would carry nuclear bombs to blow it up instead.
According to Luke, his mentor is Obi-Wan, and his friends are Han Solo, R2D2, and C3PO. They are fighting against the enemy, Darth Vader, in the special world of the Death Star.

Underutilised items may seem useless to some, but they can be an asset to others. With the advent of the internet, online communities have found a way to make money from sharing underused assets. Using websites and social media groups that facilitate buying and selling of second-hand goods, it is now easier for people to share things with each other. And this is known as the sharing economy.

Around the 18th and 19th centuries two main ideas about dreams became popular. One was the idea that the things we see in our dreams represent things hidden from our conscious mind. Freud believed that if we understand what dreams are telling us, we can understand our hidden feelings and the problems they cause. However, the other theory said that dreams are just a collection of random activity in the brain while it's organising memories and events from the day. When we wake up, we try to make sense of these random images and feelings and put them into some sort of story. The first idea is that dreams represent hidden feelings and problems. The second idea is that dreams are just random activity in the brain. The first idea is that Freud believed that dreams tell us about our hidden feelings and problems. The second idea is that dreams are just random activity in the brain. The first idea is that Freud believed that dreams tell us about our hidden feelings and problems. The second idea is that dreams are just random activity in the brain. The first idea is that Freud believed that dreams tell us about our hidden feelings and problems. The second idea is that dreams are just random activity in the brain. The first idea is that Freud believed that dreams tell us about our hidden feelings and problems.

I'm a freelancer and work for myself. This is great because I am in control of what I do and how I spend my time. At first, I was working from home, but I found it really hard to concentrate. There were just too many distractions around: housework that needed doing, another cup of tea, my family members wanting my attention for various things. So I started to go to a nearby café to work, but the Wi-Fi connection wasn't ideal and I found myself drinking too much coffee. In the end, I decided to rent a desk in a co-working space with five other freelancers like myself. I liked getting dressed to go to work in the morning and being able to focus in an office environment.

Whether NASA can get the money to build NEOCam, a 0.5-metre space telescope, will determine their success. If they get the money, they can probably achieve their goal in ten years. Once they have the data, the team will need to figure out how to protect the Earth from the big asteroids.

Canada's two friends worked for a year to buy only food. They learned how to live without buying electrical goods, clothes, or things for the house. For the next stage, they gave up services, such as haircuts, eating out at restaurants, or buying petrol for their cars. In one year, they'd saved $55,000.

Pi decides to be all three religions at once. His family and teachers are surprised, but they let him choose his own religion. Pi says, 'I just want to love God'. From that moment on, his family and teachers support him in his decision.

Some people believe that writing down your dreams can open your mind to lucid dreaming. Lucid dreams are dreams in which you're aware you're dreaming, and you can make decisions to affect the events of your dreams. So, maybe you can turn a nightmare into a safe-feeling dream, or you can direct the plot of your dream like a film director. Then, instead of just interpreting your dreams, you'll be creating them, though you might want to have some dreams that allow your subconscious to tell you what's on your mind!

The charity shops can't sell all the unwanted clothes that people donate to them because the fast fashion goes out of style quickly and is often of poor quality, so huge quantities of clothes end up being thrown away and a lot of clothes that charities can't sell are sent abroad, causing economic and environmental problems.

Meagan McGrath from Canada has climbed the highest mountain on each continent, ridden a bike across Canada, and run a long-distance race in the Sahara Desert in 45ºC heat. But perhaps her most remarkable journey was a skiing trip to the South Pole. On the first day, she fell into a glacier and had to be rescued. Many of us would have given up at that point, but Meagan decided to carry on. She reached the South Pole forty days later, having pulled a sledge with a tent and all her food behind her through freezing conditions and ice storms.

Blek le Rat started painting rats on walls of his home city Paris. Nowadays he tries to make people think about social issues and problems. He paints pictures of homeless people in big cities to encourage residents to think about the problem of homelessness.

In some places, councils have tried to encourage artists not to paint graffiti on walls by allowing them to work in designated areas. Taiwan is one such place and there are 'graffiti zones' where artists are free to paint and write on walls. In São Paulo in Brazil, the city council has even allowed some graffiti artists to paint on the subway trains.

Faith47 is from Cape Town in South Africa. She paints big, colourful pictures of people and animals, and likes to explore different locations. Her work is found on pavements, in empty factories, and on abandoned cars. She likes the fact that most street art is temporary and will soon be removed by weather or cleaners from the city council. For her, this reflects how life is full of change with its cycle of endings and new beginnings.

In her previous job, Gabriela was used to a high power distance culture where leaders made big decisions and were not often challenged. In her Swedish team, however, they were used to working in a low power distance culture where leaders acted as coaches or mentors who encouraged independent thought and expected to be challenged.

When Gabriela became aware of the cultural differences between her and her team, she took the initiative to have an open conversation with them about their feelings about her leadership. Pleased to be asked for their thoughts, Gabriela's team openly expressed that they were not used to being told what to do. They enjoyed having more room for initiative and creative freedom. When she told her team exactly what she needed them to do, they felt that she didn't trust them to do their job well. They realised that Gabriela was taking it personally when they tried to challenge or make changes to her decisions, and were able to explain that it was how they'd always worked.

Os Gêmeos are twin brothers from São Paulo. They paint everything from tags to huge, colourful pictures of people on the sides of buildings. Their work is big that they need cranes to help them work. In 2007, they covered whole of a castle in Scotland with paint.

People have been painting and writing on walls throughout history. In prehistoric times, people in Africa and Europe used to paint pictures of animals and people in caves. Graffiti has been found on buildings at ancient sites in Greece, Italy, Syria and Iraq. In the Roman town of Pompeii, archaeologists have found numerous examples of graffiti written in Latin. These include religious, political and romantic messages, and even some magic spells!

Have you ever dreamt of climbing Mount Everest or walking to the South Pole? Many people try to climb the world's highest mountains or walk across continents. Unlike the explorers of the past, today's adventurers use modern technology like GPS and satellite phones. Many people travel to raise awareness about environmental issues or to help others and raise money for charities.

The first is DART – the Double Asteroid Redirection Test. Plans are scheduled to test DART on the moon of an asteroid called Didymos. The impact of DART should knock the asteroid out of its orbit so that Earth-based telescopes can pick it up.

The young heroine of the story, a sixteen year old girl named Katniss Everdeen, has lost her father in a mining accident and has to provide food for her family. She hunts in the woods around District 12 with her friend Gale and becomes very good with a bow and arrow. When her younger sister, Prim, is chosen as one of the tributes, Katniss volunteers to go instead. The other tribute from District 12 is a boy named Peeta, and Katniss soon finds herself in a complicated relationship with him.
Now you can start connecting your dreams to the events and feelings in your daily life.
Historically, more bridges were made of wood and were more likely to catch fire because of the sparks created by the steel wheels and steel tracks on old-fashioned train bridges.

They are being used to express ideas and opinions, and are becoming more widely accepted by the art world. Street artists are becoming more popular as they are more than just decorative pieces. They are being used to express ideas and opinions, and are becoming more widely accepted by the art world. Many street artists are traveling and working around the globe, sharing their work and ideas with a global audience. Street artists are becoming more popular as they are more than just decorative pieces. They are being used to express ideas and opinions, and are becoming more widely accepted by the art world. Many street artists are traveling and working around the globe, sharing their work and ideas with a global audience. The art world is giving more recognition to street art as a legitimate art form. Street artists are becoming more popular as they are more than just decorative pieces. They are being used to express ideas and opinions, and are becoming more widely accepted by the art world. Many street artists are traveling and working around the globe, sharing their work and ideas with a global audience. The art world is giving more recognition to street art as a legitimate art form. Suzanne Collines has always found news upsetting. When she was a child, her father was a pilot in the US Air Force and he fought in Vietnam. Her mother tried to protect her by not telling her what was happening in the war, but she still saw news programmes about the war and knew that her dad was there. It was a very frightening experience for her.

In a survey conducted by PwC, more than 40,000 millennials were asked about workplace culture, communication and working styles, pay structure, career development, work-life balance, etc. In a separate survey conducted by Deloitte, more than 10,000 millennials were asked about their perceptions of threats and opportunities in the complex world of work.

Erik Weihenmayer from the United States is a multi-adventurer. He has travelled to many places, like Morocco, the Grand Canyon, and Everest. He is blind, but he still enjoys going on trips. He tries to encourage people with disabilities to live active lives. Erik takes groups of young blind people on climbing expeditions.

Democratised online marketplaces are now providing a chance for parents to make some money. To give an example, parents who are busy might not have set up a stall at the local market or car boot sale to sell their children's old things, but with online marketplaces, parents are now able to sell their children's hardly worn clothes and the expensive equipment they have invested in, so as to put some cash into their pockets.

Pi and Richard Parker spend 227 days in a lifeboat. They endure hunger, illness, and exhaustion. They survive violent storms and the burning heat of the Pacific sun. At times, Pi finds comfort in his religions, but loneliness and despair also occur. Finally, the Mexican coast appears, and everything changes. You'll have to read the book to find out what happens to Pi and Richard Parker once land is in sight.

Chloe went up to her bedroom to relax after school. She didn't have any homework to do, but she wanted to enjoy the quiet time before her parents got home and the house filled up with evening sounds. She liked this time of day because she could play with her pet rats.

In 2010, NASA identified and logged 90 percent of the 887 near-Earth objects, or NEOs, which are the size of mountains and are within 50 million kilometers of Earth's orbit.  With 50 left to log, NASA says none of the 887 are a significant danger to the planet.

Having decided to go to school, Auggie then has to face his first day. Like every child starting at a new school, he is really anxious. But because of the way he looks, it's an agonising experience. Nobody wants to sit next to him and he notices other kids staring at him or talking about him behind their hands. Fortunately, he makes friends with Jack, a boy in his class, and Summer, a girl he chats with at lunch. But it's not just the first day that's hard. Auggie soon learns that his classmates don't want to touch him for fear of catching 'the plague'. As he goes through the school year, Auggie goes through many intense ups and downs till finally an unexpected and traumatic event at a school camp changes things completely.

The two men looked towards the northern end of the property. It stretched as far as the eye could see. Even the fences were barely visible from where they stood. However bored and rebellious a teenage boy might get, it wasn't possible to escape on foot. Sam looked at the biggest of the horses, kicking at the ground with its heavy hooves. Could the boy ride? he wondered. There was a whole load of trouble a good rider could get into out here, miles away from anyone. But maybe there was even more trouble for someone who knew nothing about horses and wanted to get away from his father.

Over 4,000 climbers, aged thirteen to eighty, went to the top of Everest. Even though climbing high mountains in freezing conditions is very dangerous, the best climbers now look for new challenges. Gerlinde Kaltenbrunner from Austria fell in love with climbing as a teenager. She was a nurse, but she kept climbing in her free time.

Gerlinde decided to climb all the world's 8,000 metre peaks after climbing Everest. She does this to increase the challenge. This is risky because low oxygen levels at high mountains can affect brain and body functioning. Gerlinde uses her fame to support a charity for poor children and orphans in Nepal.

People buy things that they think will be useful, but they don't always get to use them. They buy a thick coat even if they live in a warm country, a new smartphone even if they already have one, a car that they only use on weekends, or a guest room that is turned into a storage space.
Dreams have been associated with prophecy in many cultures. Many people have had dreams about events or people and later, those dreams have come true in real life.

The biggest and most expensive transportation projects in the world are bridges. They are important links that carry cars, trucks, and trains across bodies of water, mountain gorges, or other roads. Bridges are very important in civil engineering and are often subject to intense scrutiny, especially when they collapse.

After a few days of frustration, Gabriela emailed her manager about the issues she was facing with her team. Her manager simply asked her if she felt her team was still performing and what she thought would help her better collaborate with her team members. Gabriela felt her manager wasn't managing the situation satisfactorily.

Some dogs have learnt to use the city's metro system to get from one part of their territory to another. Dogs have even learnt to use the metro system, to travel from one part of their territory to another. They use their excellent sense of smell to find the right train, and they have learnt to recognise the names of stations they hear in announcements. The metro passengers have now got so used to the sight of dogs on the trains that they travel largely unnoticed by locals.

Ed Stafford from the UK is the first person to walk the length of the Amazon River. He started from a small stream in the Andes mountains of Peru and arrived at the river's mouth in Brazil two years and four months later, having walked 6,000 kilometres. The Amazon rainforest is home to poisonous snakes, crocodiles and jaguars, so Ed was in constant danger. Luckily, he survived with nothing worse than a few thousand mosquito and ant bites.

In Britain, people spend more than £1,000 on new clothes a year, which is about four per cent of their income. That might not sound like much, but that figure hides two worrying trends for society and for the environment. First, a lot of that spending is via credit cards. British people currently owe around £670 per adult to credit card companies. That's 66 per cent of the average wardrobe budget. Also, people are using credit cards to buy things they don't need. Britain throws away 300,000 tons of clothing a year, most of which goes to landfill sites.

Ed's journey would have been impossible without technology. He used a radio to ask the people of the rainforest for food and permission to cross their land. Many of them came to meet him and helped guide him through the difficult terrain. As he walked, Ed wrote a blog, recording his day-to-day experiences. He used the media interest in his trip to protest about the destruction of the rainforest and raise money for children's charities in Brazil and Peru.

Businesses are making use of the resources of the sharing economy to gain extra cash. A business model that has become popular sees companies providing an online platform that puts customers in contact with those who can provide a particular product or service. Companies like Airbnb and Uber act as middlemen for people to make money from their unused rooms and houses and let them out as accommodation. Another example is Uber, which encourages people to use their own cars as taxis to make some extra cash in their free time.

Zoos help endangered species survive by providing a safe environment for them to live and breed. In this environment, the species can increase their genetic diversity and become healthier. In some cases, zoos help by releasing animals back into the wild. This increases the genetic diversity of the species and helps the population to survive. By doing this, zoos provide a safeguard for the species and help to protect them from extinction.

Both of these kinds of accidents are extremely rare, but boats and trains can cause a bridge to collapse for different reasons. With trains, it's the velocity of the impact that can bring a bridge down. With boats, it's the very large mass they have that can bring about the collapse, even if they are moving very slowly when it occurs. The best way to avoid bridge failures is to plan for them. Modern technologies that can detect structural weakness, safer working environments and better designs can all help to reduce these terrible accidents.
Pi is terrified of the animals in the boat. Then he remembers that the tiger is seasick and has no interest in eating him. Now he can relax and enjoy his journey with Richard Parker.
Pi's family and the sailors drown, but Pi is left alone with a hyena, zebra, orang-utan and a tiger. Pi uses his ingenuity to survive and ultimately escapes from the lifeboat.

The Hunger Games is a very popular book for teenagers and young people by the American author Suzanne Collins. Since it was published in 2008 it has been translated into 26 different languages and has sold over a million electronic copies around the world. It is also the first book for young readers to sell more than a million copies. The Hunger Games is now a popular Hollywood film and is just as popular. It made $152.5 million in its opening weekend in North America alone.
The part of our brain that controls language becomes less active when we're asleep, while the part that controls emotions becomes more active.

Having good relationships is a big part of being happy. Most happy people have friends and family close to them, and they make time for each other. They also need one person they can talk to about their feelings – called'self-disclosure'. This is just one person, and they don't need lots of friends to chat with. What's most important is having someone to talk to about big feelings. Some people need to learn how to listen well to others in order to develop strong relationships.

The brain's ability to develop new skills is an important aspect of human development.  People tend to praise the end result rather than the process, but research suggests that praising effort and process can lead to better development of new skills and talents.

The rover analyses the air around it periodically, and in 2014 it found the air contained another of the most basic organic molecules and a key ingredient of natural gas: methane. One of the characteristics of methane is that it only survives a few hundred years. This means that something, somewhere on Mars, is replenishing the supply. According to NASA, Mars emits thousands of tons of methane at a time. The level of methane rises and falls at seasonal intervals in the year, almost as if the planet is breathing it.

Carol Dweck of Stanford University gave a group of ten-year-olds problems that were slightly too hard for them. One group reacted positively, said they loved challenge and understood that their abilities could be developed. She says they had a 'growth mindset' and are focused on what they can achieve in the future. But another group of children felt that their intelligence was being judged and they had failed. They had a 'fixed mindset' and were unable to imagine improving. Some of these children said they might cheat in the future; others looked for someone who had done worse than them to boost their self-esteem.

Horror films love uninhabited places. This could be an abandoned hospital, a scary empty house or a ghost town. There's something about lonely, empty places. What was it like when people lived there? Why did they leave? Maybe it's also that they are so quiet, which can be very scary too. Of course, abandoned places are also handy for horror film directors in that it's more believable that you will have no phone coverage there either.

No matter what kind of house you have, the basement is a scary place in horror films. That's usually where something is hiding or where the bad guy has hidden their tools. Basements are always dark and often damp. You can only reach them by a narrow staircase. And basements are always creepy, even when there isn't anything down there.

Gary Collins, an off-duty policeman, was watching the London riots on TV. He immediately recognised several people and cut his holiday short to help with identification. He ended up spending six months going through the CCTV film and managed to identify 190 people, many from their eyes alone. His help was of decisive importance in the investigation. Even with 200,000 hours of footage, facial recognition software managed to identify just one person.

As for me, I think it's amazing to think that one day we'll be able to do things we can't do today. Imagine if you could put a computer in your head! Soon we'll be able to do things like that and it's going to become more and more common.

It was a good talk and the speaker really hit the nail on the head with a couple of things. Take parental influence, for instance. How can we expect teenagers not to text while doing their homework when they witness their parents posting on social media while cooking the evening meal or waiting at a red light? She also made a valid point about people wanting to be in two or several places at once. So they switch back and forth between their real-life and online conversations. I see it all the time with my teenage daughter and her friends. They arrange to meet and then sit together in silence while each one engages in a different conversation online.

As for news stories that make us think the world is an increasingly violent place, there is cause for some optimism too. Between the end of World War II and 1990, there were 30 wars that killed more than 100,000 people. Today there are still civil wars, but countries are mostly co-existing more peacefully than in the past. However, terrorism has shot up in the last few years and, since World War II, wars have killed many more civilians than soldiers. Even for civilians, though, the statistics are not all bad. Although deaths are nine times more likely to be a result of violent crime than political conflict, the global murder rate fell slightly, from 8 per 100,000 people in 2000 to about 5.3 in 2015.

Wasfia has dedicated her life to supporting human rights and has witnessed numerous humanitarian projects in her homeland to educate and train women and girls, but once too often they have been left with nothing when such projects have stopped running. Wasfia saw that Bangladesh needed to stand up for itself and so she brought together two of her passions, mountaineering and human rights, in order to try and change attitudes towards women in her country. She originally took up climbing while working on humanitarian campaigns in Tibet and Nepal, as in a coastal, primarily flat country like Bangladesh most people have never set eyes on a mountain. Her campaign seems to be doing the trick as fellow countrymen and women are sitting up and taking notice along with the rest of the world.

The majority of people believe that developing countries are in a difficult situation: suffering from incredible poverty, governed by dictators and with little hope for any meaningful change. But, surprisingly, this is far from the truth. The reality is that a great transformation is occurring. Over the past 20 years, more than 700 million people have increased their income and come out of poverty. Additionally, six million fewer children die every year from disease, millions more girls are in school and millions of people have access to clean water.

In order to give good feedback, managers should deliver positive comments that reinforce employees' good performance, rather than just providing a form of sugarcoating that can be perceived as routine and diminishing its value.

I'm a member of the Campaign to Stop Killer Robots. Forget the movie image of a terrifying Terminator stamping on human skulls and think of what's happening right now: military machines like drones, gun turrets and sentry robots are already being used to kill with very little human input. The next step will be autonomous'murderbots', following orders but ultimately deciding who to kill on their own. It seems clear to me that this would be completely unethical and dangerous for humanity. We need to be very cautious indeed about what we ask machines to do.

Overall, the number of English language learners is greater than the number of learners of other languages. English is spoken in the most countries. However, Chinese has the most native speakers. There is a weak link between the number of native speakers and the number of learners, but a strong link between the number of learners and the number of countries where the language is spoken.

Your manager stops you and says she needs to have a word about your performance in the recent project. You wonder what you might have done wrong. When you step into her office on Monday morning she begins by praising you for the good work you've done on the project, and you wonder if this is the obligatory praise that starts off the typical 'feedback sandwich'. You know how the feedback sandwich goes: say something nice, say what you really want to say, say something nice again.

The song "Born in the U.S.A." carries emotional weight. Behind catchy rock melodies are stories of the dark side of the American dream. Many tracks deal with the struggles of hardworking ordinary people and the bitterness and anger they feel as life doesn't bring them riches or glory. The song "Glory Days" is about people in a small town looking back at when they were young and had the world at their feet. The song "Downbound Train" tells the story of a young man whose life is ruined when he loses his job. It's not hard to imagine that the artist is channelling real people he knew and the life he might have had if he hadn't become a star. The album will leave you in no doubt of the unique and extraordinary talent of the Boss.

Lewis wants to see the number of marine protected areas increase from 3% to 10% because he wants to protect the environment. He has seen the destruction of coral reefs and underwater deserts during his expeditions. He thinks nature can recover if it has space. If we don't start taking care of the seas, we may face a big problem.

The best-selling author, Terrie Sharp, was born on a housing estate with the highest crime rate in Glasgow, where she learned to stay quiet and keep out of trouble, but now she's open about her past and appears on popular daytime shows and at writing conferences throughout the UK.

Are things getting worse every day? Is progress an impossible goal? In Enlightenment Now, Steven Pinker looks at the big picture of human progress and finds good news. We are living longer, healthier, freer and happier lives. The real problem, Pinker argues, is that the Enlightenment values of reason and science are under attack. When commentators and demagogues appeal to people's tribalism, fatalism and distrust, then we are in danger of causing irreparable damage to important institutions like democracy and world co-operation.

Mobile phones have made the situation a bit more believable now. What's the solution to maintain suspense? No phone coverage! If you're a hero in a horror film, you will not have any coverage at all. Or your phone battery will die just as you are making the call. Or both.

In the 1950s, Central American commercial banana growers were facing the death of their most lucrative product, the Gros Michel banana. And now it's happening again to the Cavendish. With its easily transported, thick-skinned and sweet-tasting fruit, the Gros Michel dominated the plantations of Central America. United Fruit, the main grower and exporter in South America at the time, mass-produced its bananas in the most efficient way possible: it cloned shoots from the stems of plants instead of growing plants from seeds, and cultivated them in densely packed fields.

Spider venom is present in most species and serves the purpose of stunning or killing their prey rather than attacking humans. In fact, only 25 of the known spider species produce venom which can actually harm humans, and although spider bites can be painful, they are rarely deadly. Australia's notorious Sydney funnel-web spider has not produced any fatalities since anti-venom was developed in 1981. However, take care not to rub hairy spiders like tarantulas up the wrong way. When they feel in danger, they defend themselves by ejecting a cloud of urticating hairs. These irritating hairs then embed themselves in the skin or eyes of the attacker.

This film cliché was popular with horror movies of the late 20th century. It starts with a group of teenagers enjoying themselves, and it ends with everyone dead except one girl. At the beginning, the girl is usually innocent and shy. By the end, she has become the toughest person in the world. The last girl always wins.

If we want to know where our capability for complex language came from, we need to look at how our brains are different from other animals. This relates to more than just brain size; it is important what other things our brains can do and when and why they evolved that way. And for this there are very few physical clues; artefacts left by our ancestors don't tell us what speech they were capable of making. One thing we can see in the remains of early humans, however, is the development of the mouth, throat and tongue. By about 100,000 years ago, humans had evolved the ability to create complex sounds. Before that, evolutionary biologists can only guess whether or not early humans communicated using more basic sounds.

Girls, from a young age, are encouraged to favour arts and humanities and leave maths and physics to the boys.  The lack of positive female role models youngsters see doing science-related jobs is also a concern.  Cartoons and stories often show the crazy scientist, genius inventor, or adventurous astronaut as a man.  Furthermore, there is an unfortunate perception that scientists are geeky, have poor social skills or that their work is lonely and detached from the rest of the world.  These are false stereotypes portrayed by the media, but they may mean that girls do not identify with scientists, and see science as an unappealing career path.  If girls saw more positive female role models in science it would give them more confidence and a greater sense of belonging in those subjects.

The Scallion is printed weekly and distributed free in faculty buildings, with a readership of approximately 10,000 students. It is written and produced entirely by students. The survey shows that the newspaper is highly valued by university students and staff for entertainment, cultural enrichment and work experience. The cost of printing newspapers is significant. Furthermore, some students do not have easy access to the paper, since the only way to obtain a copy is to physically go to university. An additional environmental issue is that a large number of copies end up as litter on campus.

At Girox Foods, we are experiencing an employee turnover of 12 per cent. Although this might not seem high, the industry standard is 7 per cent. We are trying to improve the employees' experience of the workplace and retain them. We will investigate the reasons for this high employee turnover and offer recommendations to increase employee retention.

I honestly believe that the more connected we are, the more isolated we feel. I don't think this is such an issue for my generation, who've lived without technology for so long. We know how to be alone and know that it's okay to be alone. But the under 20s are another story. They're so busy communicating that they never experience the feeling of solitude and run the risk of not learning how to enjoy their own company. In addition, they're learning conversation through messages that can be edited and changed, which is not the same as learning the art of real conversation in real time with the person in front of you.
To avoid devaluing positive feedback, provide positive feedback occasionally and resist the temptation to offer criticism.
